usa: The Greensboro sit-ins, sparked by the refusal of four African American college students to move from a segregated lunch counter, began similar widespread acts of civil disobedience to protest Jim Crow laws.[317]
The Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee was founded.<sup id="cite_ref-318" class="reference">[318]</sup>
U-2 incident: A CIA U-2 spy plane was shot down while flying a reconnaissance mission over Soviet airspace.[319]

The Civil Rights Act of 1960, establishing federal inspection of local voter registration polls and penalties for those attempting to obstruct the right to vote, was signed into law.<sup id="cite_ref-320" class="reference">[320]</sup>

The first ever general election debate between presidential candidates was held between Democratic nominee John F. Kennedy and Republican nominee Richard M. Nixon.<sup id="cite_ref-321" class="reference">[321]</sup>

United States presidential election, 1960: Massachusetts Senator John F. Kennedy was elected President, defeating Vice President Richard M. Nixon and becoming the youngest person to be elected to the office of the Presidency.[322][323]
Boynton v. Virginia: In a 7–2 ruling, the Supreme Court ruled that African-Americans were protected from racial segregation on buses by the Interstate Commerce Act.[324]
The National Front for the Liberation of Vietnam was formed.<sup id="cite_ref-325" class="reference">[325]</sup>
